title: Flybe's financial turnaround gathers pace
text:
Flybe has been boosted by a rise in both revenue and passenger numbers as it continues with its business transformation. 
The good news sent shares soaring in early trading. 
The company said it was actively pursuing “long term solutions” for its surplus E195s, which cost £26 million last year. 
The maximum exposure is £80m over the next four years but the exit costs targeted are “significantly below this figure”. 
Seat capacity grew by 12.3% to 2.8 million seats during the quarter to the end of June. Passenger numbers increased by 9.8% to 2.1 million, which helped boost passenger revenue to £147.7 million. 
Saad Hammad, chief executive, said: “As we enter the next phase of our transformation, Flybe has again delivered revenue and passenger growth in the quarter, demonstrating the strength of our core business. 
“We carried significantly more customers than the same time last year and maintained our industry-leading punctuality levels. 
“We remain focused on tackling the surplus E195 aircraft, our final legacy issue, and are actively pursuing a range of solutions.”
